exampleErrors: "It Was A Blunder Mistake."
exampleCorrections: Every Sunday, I Wash My Hair.
explanation:
Correction, People! The Word 'Blunder' Means Mistake, So You Could
Say:
~ "It Was A Blunder," Or
~ "It Was A Big Mistake."
2. ~ "It Would Have Been More Better."
The Word 'Better' Itself Implies That The Option In Question Is
Superior -- The Use Of The Word 'More' In The Sentence Is, Therefore
Both Inappropriate And Unnecessary. Thus The Correct Sentence
Would Go As Follows:
~ "It Would Have Been Better."
3. ~ "Why Don't He Get Married?"
The Term 'Don't' Applies When Discussing A Plural Subject. For
Instance, "Why Don't They Get Married?" The Right Way To Phrase
That Sentence Would Be:
~ "Why Doesn't He Get Married?"

 4. ~ "I Want Two Xeroxes Of This Card."
The Term 'Xerox' Is Used In North American English As A Verb.
Actually, 'Xerox' Is The Name Of A Company That Supplies
Photocopiers! The Correct Thing To Say, Therefore, Would Be:
~ "I Want Two Photocopies Of This Card."
5. ~ "Your Hairs Are Looking Silky Today."
This Is One Of The Most Common Indian Bloopers! The Plural Of
'Hair' Is 'Hair'! Thus:
~ "Your Hair Is Looking Silky Today."
Get Ahead Reader Nasreen Haque Says, "We Must Realise That
English Is Not The Native Language Of Indians. Having Said That, We
Should Tell Ourselves, 'Yeah, I Could Go Wrong And I Could Make
Innumerable Mistakes, But Of Course There Is Always Room For
Improvement.'"
Here Are A Few Bloopers Nasreen Has Across Often:
1. ~ Loose Vs Lose:
Many People Make This Mistake. They Inevitably Interchange The
Words 'Loose' And 'Lose' While Writing. 'Lose' Means To 'Suffer A
Loss Or Defeat'. Thus, You Would Write:
~ 'I Don't Want To Lose You," And Not ' Don't Want To Loose You.'
'Loose', On The Other Hand, Means 'Not Firm' Or 'Not Fitting.' In This
Context, You Would Write,

 ~ "My Shirt Is Loose," Not "My Shirt Is Lose."

2. ~ "One Of My Friend Lives In Kolkata."
This Is One Of The Most Common Indian English Bloopers Ever! The
Correct Way Of Putting That Is:
"One Of My Friends Lives In Kolkata."
Why? Because The Sentence Implies That You Have Many Friends
Who Live In Kolkata, But You Are Referring To Only One Of These
Friends.
3. ~ Tension-Inducing Tenses.
People Often Use The Wrong Tense In Their Sentences. For Instance,
Someone Might Say:
~ "I Didn't Cried When I Saw The Movie."
Unfortunately, The Word 'Didn't' Is Never Followed By A Past Tense
Verb, In This Case 'Cried'. The Correct Way Of Putting It Would Be:
~ "I Didn't Cry When I Saw The Movie."

English Is Considered One Of The Most Difficult Languages To Learn.
After All, You Have To Keep In Mind All The Exceptions, Rules,
Irregular Tenses And Other Oddities.
Don't Abandon Hope If You're Having Trouble. Keep Reading Our
Reader-Driven, English Bloopers Series, And Before Long You'll Be

 An Expert!
Today, We Look At Contributions From Karan Shah And Shihari BN.
Karan, A 21-Year-Old English Student In New Delhi, Says That Many
People Make Mistakes With Irregular Nouns, Especially When
Changing Them Into Plural Form. He Provided The Following List:
~ I Bought New Furnitures For The Bedroom.
~ Please Bring Along The Film Equipments!
~ Display The Datas In A Graph.
~ Did You See The Deers In The Forest?
~ There Were Many Pretty Womans At The Party!
~ What Were The Different Criterias For Joining?
~ I'm Interested In Misunderstood Phenomenas.
The Common Problem Linking These Bloopers Is Using The Incorrect
Plural Form Of The Noun. All Of Them Have 'S' Added On To The End
When It Is Unnecessary. The Correct Version Would Be:
~ I Bought New Furniture For The Bedroom. (Furniture Is Plural As
Well As Singular.)
~ Please Bring Along The Film Equipment! (Equipment Is Plural As
Well As Singular.)
~ Display The Data In A Graph. (Datum Is Singular; Data Is Plural.)
~ Did You See The Deer In The Forest? (Deer Is Singular And Plural.)
~ There Were Many Pretty Women At The Party! (Woman Is Singular;

 Women Is Plural.)
~ What Were The Different Criteria For Joining? (Criterion Is Singular;
Criteria Is Plural.)
~ I'm Interested In Misunderstood Phenomena. (Phenomenon Is
Singular; Phenomena Is Plural.)
Srihari, A 36-Year-Old From Bangalore Working In IT Enabled
Services, Sent A Few Bloopers He Commonly Hears In Office.
Blooper No 1:
~ Every Sunday, I Take Headbath.

exampleErrors: I Sended That Parcel.
exampleCorrections: I Am Quite Certain That I Paid The Fee.
explanation:
This Is Common Mistake. English Has Many Irregular Verbs In The
Past Tense. Sent Is The Past Form Of Send.
~ I Sent That Parcel.
Blooper No 3:
~ I Will Call You Today Night.
Just Dissecting The Word, To-Day, Shows The Origin. It Means During
The Day. Therefore, You Should Use To-Night.
~ I Will Call You Tonight
Blooper No 4:
~ Can I Have Your Name?
~ Can I Go To The Toilet?
~ Can I Hold Your Hand?

 This Is One Of The Most Common Misuses Of A Word In The English
Language. Of Course You *Can* Have Someone's Name, Just As
Easily As You *Can* Go The Toilet Or Hold Someone's Hand. Can
Means Whether Or Not You Are Able To Do It. May Means Whether Or
Not You Have Permission To Do It.
~ May I Have Your Name?
~ May I Go To The Toilet?
~ May I Hold Your Hand?

Mistakes We Make While Speaking English Part-3..

 Terrible Grammar And Error-Riddled Speech Is Frequently A Problem
For Young Adults.
Poor English Makes You Sound Unprofessional And Can Lead To
Laughs At Your Expense! If You Need To Touch Up On Your English,
Or Just Want A Few Giggles, Read On!

Continuing Our User-Driven Series On Common English Bloopers,
Let's Highlight A Few Mistakes Overhead By Rediff.Com Users.
Shilpa Archaya Sent Several Bloopers She Encounters Frequently.
~ Please Return My Book Back.
~ Could You Repeat That Last Line Again?

In Both Cases, The Final Word Is Redundant. When You Return A
Book, You Give It Back To The Owner. When You Repeat A Line,
You're Saying It Again. They Should Read:
~ Please Return My Book.
~ Could You Repeat That Last Line?
Shilpa Also Noted The Following Common Mistake.
~ I, My Sister And Deepa Went To The Mall
'I' And 'Me' Are Always Placed At The End Of A List Of Names/
Pronouns. The Correct Usage Is:

 ~ My Sister, Deepa And I Went To The Mall.
SM Hussein From Andhra Pradesh Notes The Prevalence Of Other
Redundancies:
~ The Fish Aquarium Is Very Large.
~ The Dance Ballet Was Lovely.
In Both Cases, The Descriptive Word Is Unnecessary. An Aquarium
Houses Fish And A Ballet Is Always A Dance! The Correct Usage Is
Simply:
~ The Aquarium Is Very Large.
~ The Ballet Was Lovely.
Another Mistake Hussein Hears Frequently:
~ I Could Not Able To Do It, Sir.
In This Case, Either Able Should Be Removed Or Could Should Be
Replaced With Was. Here Are The Two Correct Possibilities:
~ I Could Not Do It, Sir.
~ I Was Not Able To Do It, Sir.

Embarrassing For The Speaker.
Our Reader-Driven Series On English Bloopers Reaches Its Fourth
Instalment; Today We Look At Erroneous Translations Overhead By
Our Readers.
Praveen Madhukar Naik, 26 From Bangalore, Repeatedly Hears These
Three Mistakes.
~ "He Said Me To Go."
This Is The Result Of A Direct Translation. In English, Direct
Commands And Directions Are Given Using The Verb 'Tell'. In This
Case, We Use The Past Tense Of 'Tell' -- Told
~ "He Told Me To Go"

~ "Please On The Fan!"
Praveen Finds This Is The Most Irritating Blooper, Because He Hears It
Every Day! In English 'On' Is Not An Action Verb In The Traditional
Sense; The 'On' Must Be Qualified With A Verb!
~ "Please Turn On The Fan" Or "Please Switch On The Fan"
~ "He Is My Cousin Brother."
This Is Another Mistake Caused By A Direct Translation; It Can Be
Heard In All Strata Of Society. English Does Not Contain A Separation/
Qualification For Female Or Male Cousins, So The Correct Way To Use
It Would Be:

 ~ "He Is My Cousin."
Gurmeet Singh Mehtab, A Corporate Language Trainer In Mumbai,
Teaches English Everyday. In Gurmeet's Experience, People Normally
Make Mistakes With Words Which Cannot Be Visualised
Independently.

These Include Helping Verbs, Prepositions, Modals, Conjunctions And
Articles. Here Are A Few Recurring Bloopers Heard Frequently By
Gurmeet.
"He Has Eaten A Mango Yesterday."
When Speaking Of The Past, Helping Verbs Like Have And Has Should
Not Be Used. Instead, The Correct Conjugation Of The Verb, In This
Case 'Ate', Is Required.
~ He Ate A Mango Yesterday
Then, There's This:
~ "He Is Loving Sangita!"
The 'Is' Is Unnecessary In These Cases. When Showing Sustained Or
Continuous Action From A Verb, The Verb Alone Suffices. This Kind
Of Error Is The Result Of A Direct Translation From The Mother
Tongue Into English.
~ "He Loves Sangita!"
Here's Another Common One:
~ "I Am Standing On The Bus Stop."
In English, The Preposition 'On' Signals Being Above, Or Literally On
Top Of, Something; It Is Rarely Used As An Indicator Of Location.
Instead, Use The Preposition 'At'.
~ "I Am Standing At The Bus Stop."
That's All For Today! Please Check Later This Week For More Reader-

 Submitted English Bloopers.

English Bloopers They've Come Across! Keep Them Coming In, And
We'll Keep Publishing. This Is The Fourth In A Series Of Articles

English
Most Of Us Are Fairly Comfortable Speaking English Informally, Even
If It Is Our Second Language. However, When We Have To Put Down
Something In Writing, We Panic!
Continuing Our English-Bloopers Series, Let's Look At A Few More
Reader Submissions. This Time, They All Deal With English As A
Written Language.
Mohammed Irfan, From Brook Software Systems, Sent These Spelling
Mistakes He Comes Across In Written Documents:
Wrong Spelling Correct Spelling
Pronounciation Pronunciation
Ballon Balloon
Grammer Grammar
Truly Truly
Recieved Received
Occassion Occasion

Rajiv Raghunath, With Conversant Info Solutions In New Delhi, Finds

 Other Common Errors While Editing Business Letters And Other
Forms Of Writing.
~ I Am Quiet Certain That I Paid The Fee.
~ I Could Hear Quite Music In The Distance.
While You May Be Certain That You Paid The Fee, No One Will Know If
You Remain 'Quiet'. Likewise, 'Quite' Music Makes No Sense. The
Authors Mixed Up The Spellings Of 'Quite' (Very) And 'Quiet' (A Soft
Sound).

itemName: Mistake: I Will Call You Today Night....
exampleErrors: I Will Call You Today Night.
exampleCorrections: May I Have Your Name?
explanation:
Just Dissecting The Word, To-Day, Shows The Origin. It Means During
The Day. Therefore, You Should Use To-Night.
The Correct Version Should Be:

 ~ I Will Call You Tonight
Blooper No 4:
~ Can I Have Your Name?
~ Can I Go To The Toilet?
~ Can I Hold Your Hand?

This Is One Of The Most Common Misuses Of A Word In The English
Language. Of Course You *Can* Have Someone's Name, Just As
Easily As You *Can* Go The Toilet Or Hold Someone's Hand. Can
Means Whether Or Not You Are Able To Do It. May Means Whether Or
Not You Have Permission To Do It.

exampleErrors:
subject                  object form          swimming is fun.



        e.g. Mr Mouton commended Heinz and me for our presentation. CORRECT!
            To check yourself, take away the proper noun (“Heinz”): Mr Mouton
            commended me.
        e.g. My tutor baked a birthday cake for my friends and me. CORRECT!
            (Check further down: use the object form after a preposition) [My tutor
            baked a birthday cake for me.]
 who (subject form) / whom (object form)

 ● e.g.      Whom shall I shout at? CORRECT! (Whom is the object)
 ● e.g.      Who answered their phone in assembly? CORRECT! (Who is the
   subject.)
 ● e.g.      To whom did you give the leave-out form? CORRECT!


Or, check out:
                 http://www.grammar-monster.com/lessons/who_whom.htm
                             http://linguistech.ca/Tips+and+Tricks+-+Who+vs.
+Whom
 Use the object form of the pronoun after a
preposition


e.g.   Between you and me, I think he will be Head Boy.

       CORRECT! (Between is the preposition)



See: https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/usage/between-you-and-me
 Use the subject form of the pronoun after the
conjunctions “than” and “as”
It is not immediately obvious because we generally omit the verb (is)
but ‘than’ is joining two clauses.

To test it for yourself, add the verb: Ma’am Van Zyl is kinder than he is.
It would not be correct to say Ma’am Van Zyl is kinder than him is.
 The
Subjunctive
  The subjunctive
A verb form that refers to actions that are possibilities rather than facts:
In the sentence "I wish I were rich", the verb "were" is in the
subjunctive.


 ● use the plural form of the verb after “if”, “wish” & “as though” when
   expressing something that is imaginary:

If I were you, I’d watch my back.
I wish I were a dolphin.
She looked as though she were exhausted.

have no
singular

 e.g. scissors, shears, trousers, pants, shorts etc.
      e.g. My scissors have been stolen.

 Irregular
nouns that
take the
singular

 Irregular nouns that take
the singular form
e.g. Geography is my worst subject.

e.g. The news is just coming in and it seems that politics   is going to
triumph.
 Reflexive
pronouns
 me/myself
Me/myself:

myself is reflexive and can only be used if “I” or “me” has already been
mentioned.

        e.g. I cut myself shaving.



        e.g. James and myself went to the concert.
exampleCorrections: James and I went to the concert.

exampleErrors: The first thing we think of is the pollution.|People are judged according to the social status.
exampleCorrections: The first thing we think of is pollution.|People are judged according to social status.
explanation: Abstract nouns or generalizations used in a broad sense do not take the definite article 'the' in English.

exampleErrors: Raise taxes for pay for the service.|Woke up early for take the train.
exampleCorrections: Raise taxes to pay for the service.|Woke up early to take the train.
explanation: To express purpose with a verb, English uses the to-infinitive ('to pay'), not 'for' + base verb.

exampleErrors: Waiting to find out what the ending will be.|They thought you will help.
exampleCorrections: Waiting to find out what the ending would be.|They thought you would help.
explanation: When looking at the future from a past perspective, 'would' is used instead of 'will'.

exampleErrors: The garbage's collection.|A cinema's enthusiast.
exampleCorrections: The garbage collection.|A cinema enthusiast.
explanation: When a noun modifies another noun (Noun Adjunct), we usually place them side-by-side without a possessive 's (e.g., 'computer room', not 'computer's room').

exampleErrors: We should use the bicycle (in general).|I want to buy the car (any car).
exampleCorrections: We should use a bicycle.|I want to buy a car.
explanation: When referring to a non-specific item or introducing it for the first time, use 'a/an' instead of 'the'.

exampleErrors: Instead to using cars.|Instead to going out.
exampleCorrections: Instead of using cars.|Instead of going out.
explanation: The prepositional phrase is 'instead of', which is followed by a gerund.

exampleErrors: It is a pleasure to meeting you.
exampleCorrections: It is a pleasure of meeting you (rare) / pleasure to meet you.
explanation: Standard phrases are 'pleasure to meet' (infinitive) or 'pleasure of meeting' (gerund). 'Pleasure to meeting' mixes both forms incorrectly.

exampleErrors: We were in the airport.
exampleCorrections: We were at the airport.
explanation: Public transport hubs (airport, station) are usually viewed as points on a journey, requiring the preposition 'at'.

exampleErrors: On October of 1878.|I was born on July.
exampleCorrections: In October of 1878.|I was born in July.
explanation: Months (without a specific day number) take the preposition 'in'.

exampleErrors: Values are important as it is inherited.|These things are good because it is free.
exampleCorrections: Values are important as they are inherited.|These things are good because they are free.
explanation: A plural antecedent (values, things) must be referenced by 'they', not 'it'.

exampleErrors: A change of our habits.|We need a change of attitude.
exampleCorrections: A change in our habits.|We need a change in attitude.
explanation: When referring to an alteration within a continuing state or pattern, we use 'change in'. 'Change of' often implies substitution (e.g., change of clothes).

exampleErrors: Although of it is difficult.|Despite of the rain.
exampleCorrections: Although it is difficult.|Despite the rain / In spite of the rain.
explanation: 'Although' is a conjunction and takes no preposition. 'Despite' is a preposition and does not take 'of'. Only 'In spite' takes 'of'.

exampleErrors: Learn phrases and write it down.|Correct your mistakes and fix it.
exampleCorrections: Learn phrases and write them down.|Correct your mistakes and fix them.
explanation: Plural nouns (phrases, mistakes) must be referred to by the object pronoun 'them', not 'it'.

exampleErrors: It is the best place I had ever been.
exampleCorrections: It is the best place I have ever been.
explanation: When describing a life experience up to the present moment (after a superlative), use the Present Perfect ('have been'), not Past Perfect ('had been').

exampleErrors: A role to solving this problem.|Play a role to helping.
exampleCorrections: A role in solving this problem.|Play a role in helping.
explanation: The noun 'role' takes the preposition 'in' followed by a gerund.

exampleErrors: An important part in our lives.|Cousins in the same age.
exampleCorrections: An important part of our lives.|Cousins of the same age.
explanation: 'Part' and 'age' relationships are expressed with 'of'. 'Part of something', 'Of the same age'.

exampleErrors: I want that our life to change.
exampleCorrections: I want our life to change.
explanation: 'Want' is followed by Object + Infinitive. It cannot be followed by a 'that' clause.

exampleErrors: Everyone make mistakes.
exampleCorrections: Everyone makes mistakes.
explanation: Indefinite pronouns like 'everyone', 'someone', and 'nobody' are grammatically singular and take singular verbs.

exampleErrors: These kind of rules.
exampleCorrections: These kinds of rules.
explanation: If the determiner is plural (These/Those), the noun must be plural (kinds/types).

exampleErrors: The next 50 years of our life.
exampleCorrections: The next 50 years of our lives.
explanation: When multiple people each possess one item (a life), the noun should be plural (lives) to reflect the distribution.

exampleErrors: Advice to taking up a hobby.
exampleCorrections: Advice for taking up a hobby.
explanation: We give advice 'on' or 'for' a topic, or advise someone 'to' do something. 'Advice to taking' is a mix of forms.

exampleErrors: In that moment I realized.
exampleCorrections: At that moment I realized.
explanation: Specific moments in time are pointed to with 'at'.

exampleErrors: Relax on the fresh air.
exampleCorrections: Relax in the fresh air.
explanation: We are surrounded by air, so we are 'in' it.

exampleErrors: We can talk anything.
exampleCorrections: We can talk about anything.
explanation: 'Talk' is intransitive; it requires the preposition 'about' to connect to a topic.

exampleErrors: It depends of the weather.|My promotion depends of my boss.
exampleCorrections: It depends on the weather.|My promotion depends on my boss.
explanation: The verb 'depend' is followed by the preposition 'on' in English, whereas in Spanish it uses 'de' (of).

exampleErrors: I dream with you every night.|She dreams with becoming a doctor.
exampleCorrections: I dream of you every night.|She dreams of becoming a doctor.
explanation: In English, we 'dream of' or 'dream about' something. 'Dream with' implies dreaming while alongside someone.

exampleErrors: He is married with a lawyer.|She wants to marry with him.
exampleCorrections: He is married to a lawyer.|She wants to marry him.
explanation: One is married 'to' a person, not 'with'. Also, the verb 'marry' takes a direct object without a preposition.

exampleErrors: I am thinking in you.|He thinks in his future.
exampleCorrections: I am thinking of you.|He thinks about his future.
explanation: When focusing the mind on a subject, English uses 'think of' or 'think about', not 'in'.

exampleErrors: Can I ask a question?|She asked a question.
exampleCorrections: Can I ask a question?|She asked a question.
explanation: Wait, this is actually correct in English. The error is usually 'Make a question'. (See next item).

exampleErrors: Can I make a question?|I want to make you a question.
exampleCorrections: Can I ask a question?|I want to ask you a question.
explanation: In English, we 'ask' questions, we do not 'make' them.

exampleErrors: Listen me carefully.|I like listening music.
exampleCorrections: Listen to me carefully.|I like listening to music.
explanation: The verb 'listen' is intransitive and requires the preposition 'to' before an object.
l1Interference: {"spanish": "Spanish 'escuchar' is transitive (escuchar m\u00fasica) and does not require a preposition."}

exampleErrors: I have seen him yesterday.|She has arrived two days ago.
exampleCorrections: I saw him yesterday.|She arrived two days ago.
explanation: The Present Perfect cannot be used with finished time words (yesterday, last year, ago). Use Past Simple.
l1Interference: {"spanish": "In Peninsular Spanish, 'Pret\u00e9rito Perfecto Compuesto' (he visto) can be used for recent past events even with specific time markers."}

exampleErrors: I live here since 2010.|She lives in London since May.
exampleCorrections: I have lived here since 2010.|She has lived in London since May.
explanation: Actions starting in the past and continuing to the present require Present Perfect (Continuous), not Present Simple.

exampleErrors: I enjoy to read books.|She enjoyed to swim.
exampleCorrections: I enjoy reading books.|She enjoyed swimming.
explanation: The verb 'enjoy' is always followed by a gerund (-ing), never the infinitive.
l1Interference: {"spanish": "Verbs like 'disfrutar' can be followed by infinitives or nouns, leading to confusion."}

exampleErrors: He suggested to go to the cinema.|She suggested me to buy it.
exampleCorrections: He suggested going to the cinema.|She suggested that I buy it.
explanation: 'Suggest' is followed by a gerund or a 'that' clause. It cannot take an indirect object + infinitive.

exampleErrors: I want that you come.|She wants that he helps.
exampleCorrections: I want you to come.|She wants him to help.
explanation: 'Want' is followed by Object + Infinitive (want someone to do something), not a 'that' clause.
l1Interference: {"spanish": "Direct translation of the subjunctive structure 'Quiero que vengas'."}

exampleErrors: Let me to go.|Please let us to enter.
exampleCorrections: Let me go.|Please let us enter.
explanation: The causative verb 'let' is followed by the bare infinitive (without 'to').

exampleErrors: I did a mistake.|Don't do mistakes.
exampleCorrections: I made a mistake.|Don't make mistakes.
explanation: We 'make' mistakes, we do not 'do' them.

exampleErrors: He said a funny joke.|Stop saying jokes.
exampleCorrections: He told a funny joke.|Stop telling jokes.
explanation: We 'tell' jokes (like stories), we do not 'say' them.
l1Interference: {"spanish": "'Contar un chiste' vs 'Decir un chiste' (say/tell confusion)."}

exampleErrors: I want to win more money at my job.|She wins a good salary.
exampleCorrections: I want to earn more money at my job.|She earns a good salary.
explanation: You 'win' a competition or lottery. You 'earn' money through work.
l1Interference: {"spanish": "Spanish uses 'ganar' for both earning salary and winning games."}

exampleErrors: I want to go to the party to know people.|I knew him yesterday at the bar.
exampleCorrections: I want to go to the party to meet people.|I met him yesterday at the bar.
explanation: 'Meet' is used for the first time you see someone. 'Know' is for existing relationships.
l1Interference: {"spanish": "Spanish uses 'conocer' for both meeting someone for the first time and knowing them."}

exampleErrors: Stuck in traffic jam.|They cause many traffic jam.
exampleCorrections: Stuck in traffic jams.|They cause many traffic jams.
explanation: When referring to multiple instances of congestion, or when using a plural quantifier like 'many', the noun 'jam' must be pluralized to 'jams'.

exampleErrors: This gives me high energy each time I went spinning.|I usually went back to the swimming pool at the weekends.
exampleCorrections: This gives me high energy each time I go spinning.|I usually go back to the swimming pool at the weekends.
explanation: If the adverb (e.g., 'each time', 'usually', 'nowadays') indicates a routine or habitual action, the Simple Present tense ('go', 'play') must be used.

exampleErrors: She try to have a calm talk with her son.|Michael try to think wisely again.
exampleCorrections: She tried to have a calm talk with her son.|Michael tried to think wisely again.
explanation: In a narrative set in the past, the verb 'try' must be in its Past Simple form: 'tried'.

exampleErrors: You can read a book, doing sport, play music.|You can start running, doing stretches, and lifting weights.
exampleCorrections: You can read a book, do sport, play music.|You can start running, do stretches, and lift weights.
explanation: When listing actions following a modal verb ('can'), all verbs must maintain the same grammatical form (the bare infinitive 'do', 'read', 'play').

exampleErrors: Many people would have many difficulty going somewhere.|I have had many problems.
exampleCorrections: Many people would have a lot of difficulty going somewhere.|I have had a lot of problems.
explanation: 'Difficulty' is usually an uncountable noun when referring to trouble or problems, requiring quantifiers like 'a lot of', 'much', or 'some', not 'many'.

exampleErrors: Is your family happy that you come back?|The waiter come and took the order.
exampleCorrections: Is your family happy that you came back?|The waiter came and took the order.
explanation: In narratives or finished past actions, the verb 'come' must be in its Past Simple form: 'came'.

exampleErrors: Late getting to our office / working place.|Found a new working place.
exampleCorrections: Late getting to our office / work place.|Found a new work place.
explanation: The standard compound noun is 'workplace' (one word) or 'work place' (noun adjunct), where 'work' functions as a modifier, not the gerund 'working'.

exampleErrors: After the design was prepared, skilled machinists prepare metal plates.|Public transport was made accessible by reducing the fares.
exampleCorrections: After the design has been prepared, skilled machinists prepare metal plates.|Public transport has been made accessible by reducing the fares.
explanation: When an action ('prepare') directly precedes and enables a current action ('prepare metal plates'), the first action should be in the Present Perfect (Active: has prepared / Passive: has been prepared) or Past Perfect, to show relevance to the present or the next past step.

exampleErrors: Bus, boats and trains are the public transport.|Comparing cars and bus, the car is more expensive than the bus.
exampleCorrections: Buses, boats and trains are the public transport.|Comparing cars and buses, the car is more expensive than the bus.
explanation: When listing multiple modes of transport, or when comparing a group of them ('cars and buses'), the noun must be plural ('Buses').

exampleErrors: Maybe traffic accidents is decreased.|A lot of important things that is possible in the future.
exampleCorrections: Maybe traffic accidents will be decreased.|A lot of important things that will be possible in the future.
explanation: When making predictions or describing future possibilities, the Simple Future tense ('will be') must be used, not the Simple Present tense.

exampleErrors: I play badminton with my family last night.|I first play badminton when I was 7 years old.
exampleCorrections: I played badminton with my family last night.|I first played badminton when I was 7 years old.
explanation: Actions completed at a specific past time (indicated by 'last night' or 'when I was...') require the Past Simple tense ('played').

exampleErrors: Mine was badminton and I am really enjoyed it when I was playing.|I am really enjoyed the party.
exampleCorrections: Mine was badminton and I really enjoyed it when I was playing.|I really enjoyed the party.
explanation: The Past Simple tense verb 'enjoyed' does not require the auxiliary verb 'am'. The construction 'I am enjoyed' is grammatically incorrect (it would imply a passive voice, 'I am being enjoyed').

exampleErrors: Because when he kissed her, he didn't feel anything, he does n't feel that the ground disappeared.|I knew him yesterday, but I don't remember his name now.
exampleCorrections: Because when he kissed her, he didn't feel anything, he didn't feel that the ground disappeared.|I knew him yesterday, but I don't remember his name now.
explanation: In reported speech or descriptions of past events, the entire sequence must remain in the past tense ('did not feel'), even if the speaker is referencing a state of being at that past time.

exampleErrors: Shared cost make the huge expense.|Cheaper compared to oil cost for using a car.
exampleCorrections: Shared costs make the huge expense.|Cheaper compared to oil costs for using a car.
explanation: When referring to multiple expenses, prices, or expenses in general (the total price of a thing), the plural noun 'costs' is required.

exampleErrors: A man open the front door.|He shouted at Tom, open the door and went away.
exampleCorrections: A man opened the front door.|He shouted at Tom, opened the door and went away.
explanation: In a past narrative, the verb must be in the Past Simple tense: 'opened'.

exampleErrors: I am keen on run during the night time.|What I like about run is going to the mountains.
exampleCorrections: I am keen on running during the night time.|What I like about running is going to the mountains.
explanation: The phrase 'keen on' is followed by a gerund (-ing form), as 'on' is a preposition.

exampleErrors: It was fun because we learn a new hip hop dance.|I learn how to live as a powerful smart girl.
exampleCorrections: It was fun because we learnt a new hip hop dance.|I learnt how to live as a powerful smart girl.
explanation: In a past narrative, the verb 'learn' must be in the Past Simple tense: 'learned' (US) or 'learnt' (UK).

exampleErrors: So we can started from the beginning.|Even kids started to learn to drive at fifteen.
exampleCorrections: So we can start from the beginning.|Even kids start to learn to drive at fifteen.
explanation: Modal auxiliary verbs (can, will, may) are always followed by the bare infinitive ('start'), not the past tense or past participle ('started').

exampleErrors: They don't like staying at home and spend their time making food.|I really like spend time on the beach.
exampleCorrections: They don't like staying at home and spending their time making food.|I really like spending time on the beach.
explanation: Verbs in a compound structure must match form (parallelism). If the first verb is a gerund ('staying'), the second must also be a gerund ('spending'). Additionally, 'like' usually takes the gerund.

exampleErrors: The time spend to go and come back would be reduced.|Max spend the rest of the day thinking.
exampleCorrections: The time spent to go and come back would be reduced.|Max spent the rest of the day thinking.
explanation: The phrase 'time spent' uses the past participle ('spent') to function as an adjective modifying 'time' (time that was spent). Also, 'spend' used as a main verb in a past narrative must be 'spent'.

exampleErrors: The humans won't be able to go to the street all day.|I will go to the gym.
exampleCorrections: The humans won't be able to go into the street all day.|I will go to the gym.
explanation: When moving from an outside area into an enclosed public space, 'go into' is more precise than 'go to'. However, 'go to the street' should simply be 'go out' or 'be on the street'.

exampleErrors: These days, public transport show no future.|A general view of human innovation show that the majority.
exampleCorrections: These days, public transport shows no future.|A general view of human innovation shows that the majority.
explanation: Uncountable singular subjects ('Public transport', 'A view') require the verb to end in '-s' in the Simple Present tense ('shows').

exampleErrors: I started to play football when I was four years.|He seemed to be 28 years.
exampleCorrections: I started to play football when I was four years old.|He seemed to be 28 years old.
explanation: The phrase for expressing age must be completed with the adjective 'old' (e.g., 'X years old').

exampleErrors: The man run to where his friends were and sought a police officer.|They were scared and run to their camp.
exampleCorrections: The man ran to where his friends were and sought a police officer.|They were scared and ran to their camp.
explanation: In a past narrative, the verb 'run' must be in its Past Simple form: 'ran'.

exampleErrors: Tired of having their house destroyed, the landlords decided to build a new house.|More house and transport networks are convenient.
exampleCorrections: Tired of having their houses destroyed, the landlords decided to build a new house.|More houses and transport networks are convenient.
explanation: Plural determiners ('their', 'more') or contexts referring to multiple dwellings require the plural noun form ('houses').

exampleErrors: If they would had to pay, then they would do it.|Going to their old house as a surprise would at least would give her the chance.
exampleCorrections: If they had to pay, then they would do it.|Going to their old house as a surprise would at least give her the chance.
explanation: In the Second/Third Conditional 'if' clause, 'would' is never used. Also, two modal verbs cannot be used back-to-back in the main clause ('would would give').

exampleErrors: As more peoples take advantage of it.|Most peoples will be using their own cars.
exampleCorrections: As more people take advantage of it.|Most people will be using their own cars.
explanation: 'People' is already the plural form of 'person' and should not be pluralized further with an 's' (except in the context of referring to different ethnic groups: 'the peoples of Africa').

exampleErrors: Public buses prevent more cars to polluting the environment.|I prevent him to go.
exampleCorrections: Public buses prevent more cars from polluting the environment.|I prevent him from going.
explanation: The verb 'prevent' requires the preposition 'from' followed by a gerund (-ing) or noun to specify the action that is stopped (prevent someone from doing something).

exampleErrors: I never imagine swimming as my favorite sport, because until my back injury, I did other sports.|While watching the film, I imagine if I was the fiancee of Adam.
exampleCorrections: I never imagined swimming as my favorite sport, because until my back injury, I did other sports.|While watching the film, I imagined if I was the fiancee of Adam.
explanation: In a past narrative (indicated by 'did other sports' or 'while watching the film'), the main verb 'imagine' must be in the Past Simple tense: 'imagined'.

exampleErrors: I used to be captivated for all the toys which were presented in TV commercials.|I hope these simple actions can be used for other people.
exampleCorrections: I used to be captivated by all the toys which were presented in TV commercials.|I hope these simple actions can be used by other people.
explanation: In the passive voice (Subject + be + Past Participle), the agent (the person/thing performing the action) is introduced by the preposition 'by' (e.g., 'written by hand').

exampleErrors: I gained lots of experiences in minute taking.|I believe that my experiences in marketing and my interpersonal skills make me a prime candidate.
exampleCorrections: I gained lots of experience in minute taking.|I believe that my experience in marketing and my interpersonal skills make me a prime candidate.
explanation: When referring to knowledge or skill gained over time, 'experience' is an uncountable noun. It is only plural ('experiences') when referring to countable, specific events (e.g., 'We had many fun experiences on the trip').

exampleErrors: We were very happy there. We really like Taxco.|Why I like football since my childhood?
exampleCorrections: We were very happy there. We really liked Taxco.|Why have I liked football since my childhood?
explanation: In a past narrative, the verb 'like' must be in the Past Simple tense ('liked') or Present Perfect if the state continues ('have liked').

exampleErrors: I helped my father with his jobs after my school.|I'm going to celebrate at my home, with my family and some friends.
exampleCorrections: I helped my father with his jobs after school.|I'm going to celebrate at home, with my family and some friends.
explanation: Certain institutions or locations (school, home, work, hospital, church) used to describe a typical activity are treated adverbially and do not require a possessive determiner.

exampleErrors: I am going to describe me so you will be able to recognize me.
exampleCorrections: I am going to describe myself so you will be able to recognize me.
explanation: When the subject and the object of the verb are the same person ('I' am describing 'I'), a reflexive pronoun ('myself') must be used.

exampleErrors: When we use a car, for general, one person is the only person who is accustomed to using their own car.|For general, I prefer the train.
exampleCorrections: When we use a car, in general, one person is the only person who is accustomed to using their own car.|In general, I prefer the train.
explanation: The fixed phrase for expressing a broad statement or generalization is 'in general', using the preposition 'in', not 'for'.

exampleErrors: The first thing we think of is the pollution.|People are judged according to the social status.
exampleCorrections: The first thing we think of is pollution.|People are judged according to social status.
explanation: Abstract nouns or generalizations used in a broad sense do not take the definite article 'the' in English.

exampleErrors: Raise taxes for pay for the service.|Woke up early for take the train.
exampleCorrections: Raise taxes to pay for the service.|Woke up early to take the train.
explanation: To express purpose with a verb, English uses the to-infinitive ('to pay'), not 'for' + base verb.

exampleErrors: Waiting to find out what the ending will be.|They thought you will help.
exampleCorrections: Waiting to find out what the ending would be.|They thought you would help.
explanation: When looking at the future from a past perspective, 'would' is used instead of 'will'.

exampleErrors: The garbage's collection.|A cinema's enthusiast.
exampleCorrections: The garbage collection.|A cinema enthusiast.
explanation: When a noun modifies another noun (Noun Adjunct), we usually place them side-by-side without a possessive 's (e.g., 'computer room', not 'computer's room').

exampleErrors: We should use the bicycle (in general).|I want to buy the car (any car).
exampleCorrections: We should use a bicycle.|I want to buy a car.
explanation: When referring to a non-specific item or introducing it for the first time, use 'a/an' instead of 'the'.

exampleErrors: Instead to using cars.|Instead to going out.
exampleCorrections: Instead of using cars.|Instead of going out.
explanation: The prepositional phrase is 'instead of', which is followed by a gerund.

exampleErrors: It is a pleasure to meeting you.
exampleCorrections: It is a pleasure of meeting you (rare) / pleasure to meet you.
explanation: Standard phrases are 'pleasure to meet' (infinitive) or 'pleasure of meeting' (gerund). 'Pleasure to meeting' mixes both forms incorrectly.

exampleErrors: We were in the airport.
exampleCorrections: We were at the airport.
explanation: Public transport hubs (airport, station) are usually viewed as points on a journey, requiring the preposition 'at'.

exampleErrors: On October of 1878.|I was born on July.
exampleCorrections: In October of 1878.|I was born in July.
explanation: Months (without a specific day number) take the preposition 'in'.

exampleErrors: Values are important as it is inherited.|These things are good because it is free.
exampleCorrections: Values are important as they are inherited.|These things are good because they are free.
explanation: A plural antecedent (values, things) must be referenced by 'they', not 'it'.

exampleErrors: A change of our habits.|We need a change of attitude.
exampleCorrections: A change in our habits.|We need a change in attitude.
explanation: When referring to an alteration within a continuing state or pattern, we use 'change in'. 'Change of' often implies substitution (e.g., change of clothes).

exampleErrors: Although of it is difficult.|Despite of the rain.
exampleCorrections: Although it is difficult.|Despite the rain / In spite of the rain.
explanation: 'Although' is a conjunction and takes no preposition. 'Despite' is a preposition and does not take 'of'. Only 'In spite' takes 'of'.

exampleErrors: Learn phrases and write it down.|Correct your mistakes and fix it.
exampleCorrections: Learn phrases and write them down.|Correct your mistakes and fix them.
explanation: Plural nouns (phrases, mistakes) must be referred to by the object pronoun 'them', not 'it'.

exampleErrors: It is the best place I had ever been.
exampleCorrections: It is the best place I have ever been.
explanation: When describing a life experience up to the present moment (after a superlative), use the Present Perfect ('have been'), not Past Perfect ('had been').

exampleErrors: A role to solving this problem.|Play a role to helping.
exampleCorrections: A role in solving this problem.|Play a role in helping.
explanation: The noun 'role' takes the preposition 'in' followed by a gerund.

exampleErrors: An important part in our lives.|Cousins in the same age.
exampleCorrections: An important part of our lives.|Cousins of the same age.
explanation: 'Part' and 'age' relationships are expressed with 'of'. 'Part of something', 'Of the same age'.

exampleErrors: I want that our life to change.
exampleCorrections: I want our life to change.
explanation: 'Want' is followed by Object + Infinitive. It cannot be followed by a 'that' clause.

exampleErrors: Everyone make mistakes.
exampleCorrections: Everyone makes mistakes.
explanation: Indefinite pronouns like 'everyone', 'someone', and 'nobody' are grammatically singular and take singular verbs.

exampleErrors: These kind of rules.
exampleCorrections: These kinds of rules.
explanation: If the determiner is plural (These/Those), the noun must be plural (kinds/types).

exampleErrors: The next 50 years of our life.
exampleCorrections: The next 50 years of our lives.
explanation: When multiple people each possess one item (a life), the noun should be plural (lives) to reflect the distribution.

exampleErrors: Advice to taking up a hobby.
exampleCorrections: Advice for taking up a hobby.
explanation: We give advice 'on' or 'for' a topic, or advise someone 'to' do something. 'Advice to taking' is a mix of forms.

exampleErrors: In that moment I realized.
exampleCorrections: At that moment I realized.
explanation: Specific moments in time are pointed to with 'at'.

exampleErrors: Relax on the fresh air.
exampleCorrections: Relax in the fresh air.
explanation: We are surrounded by air, so we are 'in' it.

exampleErrors: We can talk anything.
exampleCorrections: We can talk about anything.
explanation: 'Talk' is intransitive; it requires the preposition 'about' to connect to a topic.

exampleErrors: He was taking care of her, so he was prevented from going to university.|She felt blessed as she was given such a perfect son.
exampleCorrections: He had been taking care of her, so he had been prevented from going to university.|She felt blessed as she had been given such a perfect son.
explanation: When an ongoing action or state occurred *before* and led directly to a main past event, the Past Perfect Continuous or Simple is necessary to show the chronological priority (e.g., 'had been taking care of' vs 'was taking care of').

exampleErrors: Thank you for you attention.|Talking about you courses.
exampleCorrections: Thank you for your attention.|Talking about your courses.
explanation: 'You' is the subject or object pronoun. To show possession before a noun, the possessive determiner 'your' is required.

exampleErrors: Would do you like to join us?|No one do would want to hear.
exampleCorrections: Would you like to join us?|No one would want to hear.
explanation: Modal verbs (Would, Could, Should) act as their own auxiliary and do not require the auxiliary verb 'do' to form questions or negatives.

exampleErrors: Transportation helps us going abroad.|This helps me finding a job.
exampleCorrections: Transportation helps us go abroad.|This helps me find a job.
explanation: The verb 'help' is typically followed by the bare infinitive (verb without 'to') or the full infinitive ('to' + verb), not a gerund. The structure is: help + object + (to) + verb.

exampleErrors: You have specialized transports.|Public transports is more efficient.
exampleCorrections: You have specialized transport.|Public transport is more efficient.
explanation: The word 'transport' is generally used as an uncountable noun in British and general English when referring to the system or method of moving people/goods. 'Transports' is rarely used except to refer to emotional states or military vehicles.

exampleErrors: At sum up, in my opinion, travelling by car is better.|At sum up, the risks are high.
exampleCorrections: To sum up, in my opinion, travelling by car is better.|To sum up, the risks are high.
explanation: The fixed phrase used to introduce a conclusion is 'To sum up', using the infinitive form, not the preposition 'at'.

exampleErrors: My town really take care of the environment.|I always try to find out reasons, which take a lot of time.
exampleCorrections: My town really takes care of the environment.|I always try to find out reasons, which takes a lot of time.
explanation: The third-person singular subject ('town', 'which' referring to the process) requires the verb to end in '-s' in the present tense ('takes').

exampleErrors: My position had involved looking after groups.|I had studied English at university (simple past context).
exampleCorrections: My position involved looking after groups.|I studied English at university.
explanation: The Past Perfect ('had involved') is only needed to sequence two past actions, with the 'had' action coming first. If the experience or study is the main action of a past period, the Past Simple is correct. The verb 'involve' is often incorrectly forced into the Past Perfect.

exampleErrors: The process for make bank notes.|The idea of make a film.
exampleCorrections: The process for making bank notes.|The idea of making a film.
explanation: The preposition 'for' must be followed by a gerund (-ing) when describing the purpose, method, or content of a process or idea.

exampleErrors: Looking forward to see you in Hong Kong.|We are looking forward to see your participation.
exampleCorrections: Looking forward to seeing you in Hong Kong.|We are looking forward to seeing your participation.
explanation: The expression 'look forward to' is a phrasal verb where 'to' is a preposition, not part of an infinitive. It must be followed by a gerund (-ing) or a noun.

exampleErrors: His hobbies are listening to music, play computer games, watching football.|I believe that play soccer is an excellent activity.
exampleCorrections: His hobbies are listening to music, playing computer games, watching football.|I believe that playing soccer is an excellent activity.
explanation: When listing elements (hobbies) or using a verb as the subject of a clause, all elements must be in the same form. Here, the gerund form is required for parallelism and correct subject use.

exampleErrors: My parents and me went to the hotel.|You and me could see each other.
exampleCorrections: My parents and I went to the hotel.|You and I could see each other.
explanation: When the pronoun is part of the subject of the sentence, the subject pronoun 'I' must be used, not the object pronoun 'me'. Conventionally, 'I' is always placed last in a list.

exampleErrors: I have been playing basketball since I am little.|Since I am a child, I love dogs.
exampleCorrections: I have been playing basketball since I was little.|Since I was a child, I love dogs.
explanation: When 'since' introduces the starting point of an action that continues to the present (Present Perfect/Continuous), the 'since' clause must use the Past Simple ('was') to mark that fixed point in the past.

exampleErrors: Public transport is a much need service.|They need to think again (in past narrative).
exampleCorrections: Public transport is a much needed service.|They needed to think again.
explanation: When 'need' functions as an adjective modifying a noun (a service that is needed), the past participle form ('needed') is required. In a past narrative, the verb must also shift to past tense ('needed').

exampleErrors: We sat down on a bench.|I sat down on the chair.
exampleCorrections: We sat on a bench.|I sat on the chair.
explanation: While 'sit down' means the act of lowering oneself, when followed by a preposition of location ('on a bench'), the particle 'down' is usually redundant and should be omitted.

exampleErrors: Considered as one of the dirtiest city.|It is one of the most fascinating place.
exampleCorrections: Considered as one of the dirtiest cities.|It is one of the most fascinating places.
explanation: The expression 'one of the...' must be followed by a plural noun because the item being referred to is one member of a larger group (e.g., 'one of the cars').

exampleErrors: We could be raise a new generation.|It is said that when you survive a situation which has taken you be to the limit.
exampleCorrections: We could raise a new generation.|It is said that when you survive a situation which has taken you to the limit.
explanation: Active voice with a modal verb follows the pattern: Modal + Bare Infinitive ('could raise'). The structure 'Modal + be + Verb' is used for the passive voice or continuous forms. In the second example, 'to be' is incorrectly used as the main verb.

exampleErrors: I will start to introducing my favorite family members.
exampleCorrections: I will start by introducing my favorite family members.
explanation: To describe the method used for initiating an activity, 'start by' + gerund is the most common and structurally correct form.

exampleErrors: This cause their reproductive systems to be destroyed.|This sport cause fresh and jolly me.
exampleCorrections: This causes their reproductive systems to be destroyed.|This sport causes fresh and jolly me.
explanation: Third-person singular subjects ('This', 'The sport') require the verb to end in '-es' in the simple present tense ('causes').

exampleErrors: We agree to the often enormous salaries of football players.
exampleCorrections: We agree with the often enormous salaries of football players.
explanation: When expressing an opinion in concordance with something, use 'agree with' (agree with a person/idea). 'Agree to' implies consent or willingness to follow (agree to a plan/proposal).

exampleErrors: Lora grew up and become a very pretty adult.|She became angry and become to do that in college.
exampleCorrections: Lora grew up and became a very pretty adult.|She became angry and decided to do that in college.
explanation: In a past narrative, consecutive actions must remain in the Past Simple tense ('grew up' and 'became') for consistency.

exampleErrors: I helped my father on his jobs.|They help me to keep up on my teacher's lessons.
exampleCorrections: I helped my father with his jobs.|They help me to keep up with my teacher's lessons.
explanation: To express assistance related to a task or problem, the dependent preposition is 'with' (help with the dishes). 'On' implies physical location or topic.

exampleErrors: I just slept and watch movies at home.|I enjoyed it when I watch them.
exampleCorrections: I just slept and watched movies at home.|I enjoyed it when I watched them.
explanation: In a continuous past narrative, all verbs in a sequence of actions must be in the Past Simple tense ('slept' and 'watched').

exampleErrors: We will dispense of types of transportation.
exampleCorrections: We will dispense with types of transportation.
explanation: The phrasal verb meaning 'to get rid of' or 'no longer use' is 'dispense with', not 'dispense of'.

exampleErrors: Travelling by cars is less green.|The convenience of travelling by cars.
exampleCorrections: Travelling by car is less green.|The convenience of travelling by car.
explanation: When referring to the general method of transport, the singular uncountable form 'by car' is used. The plural 'cars' refers to specific vehicles.

exampleErrors: Only one of several reason why people use less public transport.|These are the reason why I'm great.
exampleCorrections: Only one of several reasons why people use less public transport.|These are the reasons why I'm great.
explanation: The quantifiers 'several' and 'these' require a plural countable noun ('reasons').

exampleErrors: At a late point of human history.|At this point of history.
exampleCorrections: At a late point in human history.|At this point in history.
explanation: History is conceptually treated as a container or a timeline in English. Events happen 'in' history, just as they happen 'in' time. 'Of' would imply the point belongs to history, whereas 'in' locates the point within the flow of time.

exampleErrors: I read it five hours.|She waited two days.
exampleCorrections: I read it for five hours.|She waited for two days.
explanation: Unlike Romance languages where the preposition can be omitted for duration ('lo leí cinco horas'), English strictly requires 'for' to introduce a period of time during which an action continues.

exampleErrors: Let's start of with a game.|I want to start of with an introduction.
exampleCorrections: Let's start off with a game.|I want to start off with an introduction.
explanation: The particle 'off' (double f) is used in phrasal verbs to indicate separation or, in this case, commencement ('start off', 'kick off'). 'Of' (single f) is a preposition of possession and does not fit the verb particle construction.

exampleErrors: High amounts glucose.|Large amounts money.
exampleCorrections: High amounts of glucose.|Large amounts of money.
explanation: Nouns that express quantity (amount, lot, bit, piece, type, kind) are 'partitive nouns'. They technically refer to a portion of a whole, and thus require the preposition 'of' to link to the substance being quantified.

exampleErrors: There are many options to choose.|I have no options to choose.
exampleCorrections: There are many options to choose from.|I have no options to choose from.
explanation: In relative clauses involving selection, the preposition must be retained. You 'choose FROM a list' or 'choose FROM options'. When 'options' moves to the front, 'from' must remain at the end: 'options to choose from'.

exampleErrors: On his way to home.|I went to home.
exampleCorrections: On his way home.|I went home.
explanation: In English, 'home' acts as an adverb of place when used with verbs of movement (go, drive, walk), meaning 'towards home'. Therefore, the preposition 'to' is redundant and incorrect.

exampleErrors: The last day we visited the museum.|The last day I saw him.
exampleCorrections: On the last day we visited the museum.|On the last day I saw him.
explanation: Time expressions involving specific days (Monday, birthday, Christmas Day, the last day) require the preposition 'on'. This is unlike expressions starting with 'last/next' (e.g., 'last week') which do not take prepositions. Here, 'the last day' is a noun phrase requiring 'on'.

exampleErrors: We speak about everything.|They speak about everything.
exampleCorrections: We speak about everything with each other.|They speak about everything with each other.
explanation: 'Speak' primarily describes the act of producing speech. When describing an interactive conversation or relationship, we usually add the reciprocal 'with each other' or simply use the verb 'talk', which implies conversation more naturally than 'speak'.

exampleErrors: I am interested getting to know you.|Interested learning English.
exampleCorrections: I am interested in getting to know you.|Interested in learning English.
explanation: The adjective 'interested' has a fixed dependent preposition: 'in'. It cannot be followed directly by a gerund. The pattern is always: Subject + be + interested + IN + Noun/Gerund.

exampleErrors: In the other hand, it is expensive.|But in the other hand...
exampleCorrections: On the other hand, it is expensive.|But on the other hand...
explanation: This idiomatic expression refers to the open palm of a hand holding an idea. We hold things 'on' a hand, not 'in' it (which would imply inside the flesh). The fixed phrases are 'On the one hand' and 'On the other hand'.

exampleErrors: I have a habit in using my phone.|The habit in smoking.
exampleCorrections: I have a habit of using my phone.|The habit of smoking.
explanation: The noun 'habit' takes the preposition 'of' to define the content of the habit. This follows the pattern 'The [noun] of [gerund]' (e.g., the risk of falling, the cost of living).

exampleErrors: Please check us later.|Go check him.
exampleCorrections: Please check on us later.|Go check on him.
explanation: To 'check' someone means to inspect or stop them (like checking an ID). To 'check ON' someone is a phrasal verb meaning to monitor their condition or well-being to ensure they are okay.

exampleErrors: I get out bed at 7.|Time to get out bed.
exampleCorrections: I get out of bed at 7.|Time to get out of bed.
explanation: Movement from the inside to the outside of a container requires the compound preposition 'out of'. 'Out' alone is an adverb (e.g., 'He went out'). Since 'bed' is the object being exited, 'of' is required.

exampleErrors: I wrote down an essay.|She wrote down a letter.
exampleCorrections: I wrote an essay.|She wrote a letter.
explanation: 'Write down' implies quickly recording information to remember it (like a phone number or a note). For the process of composing substantial texts like essays, letters, or books, we simply use 'write'.

exampleErrors: It has a high - density population because its small territory.
exampleCorrections: It has a high - density population because of its small territory.

exampleErrors: Although of it is an industrial city, there are many shops and department stores.
exampleCorrections: Although it is an industrial city, there are many shops and department stores.

exampleErrors: Despite it is an industrial city, there are many shops and department stores.
exampleCorrections: Although it is an industrial city, there are many shops and department stores.

exampleErrors: "It Was A Blunder Mistake."
exampleCorrections: Every Sunday, I Wash My Hair.
explanation:
Correction, People! The Word 'Blunder' Means Mistake, So You Could
Say:
~ "It Was A Blunder," Or
~ "It Was A Big Mistake."
2. ~ "It Would Have Been More Better."
The Word 'Better' Itself Implies That The Option In Question Is
Superior -- The Use Of The Word 'More' In The Sentence Is, Therefore
Both Inappropriate And Unnecessary. Thus The Correct Sentence
Would Go As Follows:
~ "It Would Have Been Better."
3. ~ "Why Don't He Get Married?"
The Term 'Don't' Applies When Discussing A Plural Subject. For
Instance, "Why Don't They Get Married?" The Right Way To Phrase
That Sentence Would Be:
~ "Why Doesn't He Get Married?"

 4. ~ "I Want Two Xeroxes Of This Card."
The Term 'Xerox' Is Used In North American English As A Verb.
Actually, 'Xerox' Is The Name Of A Company That Supplies
Photocopiers! The Correct Thing To Say, Therefore, Would Be:
~ "I Want Two Photocopies Of This Card."
5. ~ "Your Hairs Are Looking Silky Today."
This Is One Of The Most Common Indian Bloopers! The Plural Of
'Hair' Is 'Hair'! Thus:
~ "Your Hair Is Looking Silky Today."
Get Ahead Reader Nasreen Haque Says, "We Must Realise That
English Is Not The Native Language Of Indians. Having Said That, We
Should Tell Ourselves, 'Yeah, I Could Go Wrong And I Could Make
Innumerable Mistakes, But Of Course There Is Always Room For
Improvement.'"
Here Are A Few Bloopers Nasreen Has Across Often:
1. ~ Loose Vs Lose:
Many People Make This Mistake. They Inevitably Interchange The
Words 'Loose' And 'Lose' While Writing. 'Lose' Means To 'Suffer A
Loss Or Defeat'. Thus, You Would Write:
~ 'I Don't Want To Lose You," And Not ' Don't Want To Loose You.'
'Loose', On The Other Hand, Means 'Not Firm' Or 'Not Fitting.' In This
Context, You Would Write,

 ~ "My Shirt Is Loose," Not "My Shirt Is Lose."

2. ~ "One Of My Friend Lives In Kolkata."
This Is One Of The Most Common Indian English Bloopers Ever! The
Correct Way Of Putting That Is:
"One Of My Friends Lives In Kolkata."
Why? Because The Sentence Implies That You Have Many Friends
Who Live In Kolkata, But You Are Referring To Only One Of These
Friends.
3. ~ Tension-Inducing Tenses.
People Often Use The Wrong Tense In Their Sentences. For Instance,
Someone Might Say:
~ "I Didn't Cried When I Saw The Movie."
Unfortunately, The Word 'Didn't' Is Never Followed By A Past Tense
Verb, In This Case 'Cried'. The Correct Way Of Putting It Would Be:
~ "I Didn't Cry When I Saw The Movie."

English Is Considered One Of The Most Difficult Languages To Learn.
After All, You Have To Keep In Mind All The Exceptions, Rules,
Irregular Tenses And Other Oddities.
Don't Abandon Hope If You're Having Trouble. Keep Reading Our

 An Expert!
Today, We Look At Contributions From Karan Shah And Shihari BN.
Karan, A 21-Year-Old English Student In New Delhi, Says That Many
People Make Mistakes With Irregular Nouns, Especially When
Changing Them Into Plural Form. He Provided The Following List:
~ I Bought New Furnitures For The Bedroom.
~ Please Bring Along The Film Equipments!
~ Display The Datas In A Graph.
~ Did You See The Deers In The Forest?
~ There Were Many Pretty Womans At The Party!
~ What Were The Different Criterias For Joining?
~ I'm Interested In Misunderstood Phenomenas.
The Common Problem Linking These Bloopers Is Using The Incorrect
Plural Form Of The Noun. All Of Them Have 'S' Added On To The End
When It Is Unnecessary. The Correct Version Would Be:
~ I Bought New Furniture For The Bedroom. (Furniture Is Plural As
Well As Singular.)
~ Please Bring Along The Film Equipment! (Equipment Is Plural As
Well As Singular.)
~ Display The Data In A Graph. (Datum Is Singular; Data Is Plural.)
~ Did You See The Deer In The Forest? (Deer Is Singular And Plural.)
~ There Were Many Pretty Women At The Party! (Woman Is Singular;

 Women Is Plural.)
~ What Were The Different Criteria For Joining? (Criterion Is Singular;
Criteria Is Plural.)
~ I'm Interested In Misunderstood Phenomena. (Phenomenon Is
Singular; Phenomena Is Plural.)
Srihari, A 36-Year-Old From Bangalore Working In IT Enabled
Services, Sent A Few Bloopers He Commonly Hears In Office.
Blooper No 1:
~ Every Sunday, I Take Headbath.

exampleErrors: I Sended That Parcel.
exampleCorrections: I Am Quite Certain That I Paid The Fee.
explanation:
This Is Common Mistake. English Has Many Irregular Verbs In The
Past Tense. Sent Is The Past Form Of Send.
~ I Sent That Parcel.
Blooper No 3:
~ I Will Call You Today Night.
Just Dissecting The Word, To-Day, Shows The Origin. It Means During
The Day. Therefore, You Should Use To-Night.
~ I Will Call You Tonight
Blooper No 4:
~ Can I Have Your Name?
~ Can I Go To The Toilet?
~ Can I Hold Your Hand?

 This Is One Of The Most Common Misuses Of A Word In The English
Language. Of Course You *Can* Have Someone's Name, Just As
Easily As You *Can* Go The Toilet Or Hold Someone's Hand. Can
Means Whether Or Not You Are Able To Do It. May Means Whether Or
Not You Have Permission To Do It.
~ May I Have Your Name?
~ May I Go To The Toilet?
~ May I Hold Your Hand?

 Terrible Grammar And Error-Riddled Speech Is Frequently A Problem

Poor English Makes You Sound Unprofessional And Can Lead To

Continuing Our User-Driven Series On Common English Bloopers,
Let's Highlight A Few Mistakes Overhead By Rediff.Com Users.
Shilpa Archaya Sent Several Bloopers She Encounters Frequently.
~ Please Return My Book Back.
~ Could You Repeat That Last Line Again?

In Both Cases, The Final Word Is Redundant. When You Return A
Book, You Give It Back To The Owner. When You Repeat A Line,
You're Saying It Again. They Should Read:
~ Please Return My Book.
~ Could You Repeat That Last Line?
Shilpa Also Noted The Following Common Mistake.
~ I, My Sister And Deepa Went To The Mall
'I' And 'Me' Are Always Placed At The End Of A List Of Names/
Pronouns. The Correct Usage Is:

 ~ My Sister, Deepa And I Went To The Mall.
SM Hussein From Andhra Pradesh Notes The Prevalence Of Other
Redundancies:
~ The Fish Aquarium Is Very Large.
~ The Dance Ballet Was Lovely.
In Both Cases, The Descriptive Word Is Unnecessary. An Aquarium
Houses Fish And A Ballet Is Always A Dance! The Correct Usage Is
Simply:
~ The Aquarium Is Very Large.
~ The Ballet Was Lovely.
Another Mistake Hussein Hears Frequently:
~ I Could Not Able To Do It, Sir.
In This Case, Either Able Should Be Removed Or Could Should Be
Replaced With Was. Here Are The Two Correct Possibilities:
~ I Could Not Do It, Sir.
~ I Was Not Able To Do It, Sir.

Errant Hindi-English Translations!
*****************************
English Bloopers.. Part-4 Of Mistakes We Make While Speaking
English

 Praveen Madhukar Naik, Gurmeet Singh Mehtab

T He Most Humorous And Head-Scratching Bloopers Occur When
Many Of Us Attempt To Translate From Our Mother-Tongue Directly
Into English. The Results Can Be Hard On The Ears And
Embarrassing For The Speaker.
Our Reader-Driven Series On English Bloopers Reaches Its Fourth
Instalment; Today We Look At Erroneous Translations Overhead By
Our Readers.
Praveen Madhukar Naik, 26 From Bangalore, Repeatedly Hears These
Three Mistakes.
~ "He Said Me To Go."
This Is The Result Of A Direct Translation. In English, Direct
Commands And Directions Are Given Using The Verb 'Tell'. In This
Case, We Use The Past Tense Of 'Tell' -- Told
~ "He Told Me To Go"

~ "Please On The Fan!"
Praveen Finds This Is The Most Irritating Blooper, Because He Hears It
Every Day! In English 'On' Is Not An Action Verb In The Traditional
Sense; The 'On' Must Be Qualified With A Verb!
~ "Please Turn On The Fan" Or "Please Switch On The Fan"
~ "He Is My Cousin Brother."
This Is Another Mistake Caused By A Direct Translation; It Can Be
Heard In All Strata Of Society. English Does Not Contain A Separation/
Qualification For Female Or Male Cousins, So The Correct Way To Use
It Would Be:

 ~ "He Is My Cousin."
Gurmeet Singh Mehtab, A Corporate Language Trainer In Mumbai,
Teaches English Everyday. In Gurmeet's Experience, People Normally
Make Mistakes With Words Which Cannot Be Visualised
Independently.

These Include Helping Verbs, Prepositions, Modals, Conjunctions And
Articles. Here Are A Few Recurring Bloopers Heard Frequently By
Gurmeet.
"He Has Eaten A Mango Yesterday."
When Speaking Of The Past, Helping Verbs Like Have And Has Should
Not Be Used. Instead, The Correct Conjugation Of The Verb, In This
Case 'Ate', Is Required.
~ He Ate A Mango Yesterday
Then, There's This:
~ "He Is Loving Sangita!"
The 'Is' Is Unnecessary In These Cases. When Showing Sustained Or
Continuous Action From A Verb, The Verb Alone Suffices. This Kind
Of Error Is The Result Of A Direct Translation From The Mother
Tongue Into English.
~ "He Loves Sangita!"
Here's Another Common One:
~ "I Am Standing On The Bus Stop."
In English, The Preposition 'On' Signals Being Above, Or Literally On
Top Of, Something; It Is Rarely Used As An Indicator Of Location.
Instead, Use The Preposition 'At'.
~ "I Am Standing At The Bus Stop."

Continuing Our English-Bloopers Series, Let's Look At A Few More
Reader Submissions. This Time, They All Deal With English As A
Written Language.
Mohammed Irfan, From Brook Software Systems, Sent These Spelling
Mistakes He Comes Across In Written Documents:
Wrong Spelling Correct Spelling
Pronounciation Pronunciation
Ballon Balloon
Grammer Grammar
Truly Truly
Recieved Received
Occassion Occasion

Rajiv Raghunath, With Conversant Info Solutions In New Delhi, Finds

 Other Common Errors While Editing Business Letters And Other
Forms Of Writing.
~ I Am Quiet Certain That I Paid The Fee.
~ I Could Hear Quite Music In The Distance.
While You May Be Certain That You Paid The Fee, No One Will Know If
You Remain 'Quiet'. Likewise, 'Quite' Music Makes No Sense. The
Authors Mixed Up The Spellings Of 'Quite' (Very) And 'Quiet' (A Soft
Sound).

itemName: Mistake: I Could Hear Quiet Music In The Distance....
exampleErrors: I Could Hear Quiet Music In The Distance.
exampleCorrections: Every Sunday, I Wash My Hair.
explanation:
Here's Another Common Error
~ Did You Go Their As Well?
~ I Gave You They're Contact Details In My Last E-Mail.
~ There Going To The Office Tomorrow.
There/ They're/ Their Are Used Mistakenly All The Time. Their Is A
Possessive Pronoun; While They're Is A Contraction Of 'They Are.'
So, If You Were Using The Correct Words, You Would Write:
~ Did You Go There As Well?
~ I Gave You Their Contact Details In My Last E-Mail.
~ They're Going To The Office Tomorrow.
Here Are Some More Common Mistakes People Make:
~ There Are Meetings At 2 Pm And At 5 Pm, With A Brake In Between.
~ Will Changing Jobs Hurt My Carrier?
Again, Here, The Wrong Spelling Has Been Used For Similar Sounding
Words. A 'Brake' Is A Restraint Used To Stop A Vehicle. A Carrier Is
Someone Or Something That Carries Objects, Like A Carrier Ship.
The Correct Words To Use Here Would Be:
~ There Are Meetings At 2 Pm And At 5 Pm, With A Break In Between.
~ Will Changing Jobs Hurt My Career?
That's All For Today, But Remember, Writing In English Can

 Sometimes Be Especially Tricky! You Need To Be Careful; Mistakes
Like These Can Make Your Letters Seem Unprofessional.

English Is Considered One Of The Most Difficult Languages To Learn.
After All, You Have To Keep In Mind All The Exceptions, Rules,
Irregular Tenses And Other Oddities.

Today, We Look At Contributions From Karan Shah And Shihari BN.
Karan, A 21-Year-Old English Student In New Delhi, Says That Many
People Make Mistakes With Irregular Nouns, Especially When
Changing Them Into Plural Form. He Provided The Following List:
~ I Bought New Furnitures For The Bedroom.

 ~ Please Bring Along The Film Equipments!
~ Display The Datas In A Graph.
~ Did You See The Deers In The Forest?
~ There Were Many Pretty Womans At The Party!
~ What Were The Different Criterias For Joining?
~ I'm Interested In Misunderstood Phenomenas.
The Common Problem Linking These Bloopers Is Using The Incorrect
Plural Form Of The Noun. All Of Them Have 'S' Added On To The End
When It Is Unnecessary. The Correct Version Would Be:
~ I Bought New Furniture For The Bedroom. (Furniture Is Plural As
Well As Singular.)
~ Please Bring Along The Film Equipment! (Equipment Is Plural As
Well As Singular.)
~ Display The Data In A Graph. (Datum Is Singular; Data Is Plural.)
~ Did You See The Deer In The Forest? (Deer Is Singular And Plural.)
~ There Were Many Pretty Women At The Party! (Woman Is Singular;
Women Is Plural.)
~ What Were The Different Criteria For Joining? (Criterion Is Singular;
Criteria Is Plural.)

 ~ I'm Interested In Misunderstood Phenomena. (Phenomenon Is
Singular; Phenomena Is Plural.)
Srihari, A 36-Year-Old From Bangalore Working In IT Enabled
Services, Sent A Few Bloopers He Commonly Hears In Office.
Blooper No 1:
~ Every Sunday, I Take Headbath.

exampleErrors: I Sended That Parcel.
exampleCorrections: I Sent That Parcel.
explanation:
This Is Common Mistake. English Has Many Irregular Verbs In The
Past Tense. Sent Is The Past Form Of Send.

itemName: Mistake: I Will Call You Today Night....
exampleErrors: I Will Call You Today Night.
exampleCorrections: May I Have Your Name?
explanation:
Just Dissecting The Word, To-Day, Shows The Origin. It Means During
The Day. Therefore, You Should Use To-Night.
The Correct Version Should Be:

 ~ I Will Call You Tonight
Blooper No 4:
~ Can I Have Your Name?
~ Can I Go To The Toilet?
~ Can I Hold Your Hand?

This Is One Of The Most Common Misuses Of A Word In The English
Language. Of Course You *Can* Have Someone's Name, Just As
Easily As You *Can* Go The Toilet Or Hold Someone's Hand. Can
Means Whether Or Not You Are Able To Do It. May Means Whether Or
Not You Have Permission To Do It.

 Use the subject form of the pronoun after the

It is not immediately obvious because we generally omit the verb (is)

To test it for yourself, add the verb: Ma’am Van Zyl is kinder than he is.

subjunctive.

exampleErrors: The first thing we think of is the pollution.|People are judged according to the social status.
exampleCorrections: The first thing we think of is pollution.|People are judged according to social status.
explanation: Abstract nouns or generalizations used in a broad sense do not take the definite article 'the' in English.

exampleErrors: We ask to the assistant for a bag.|I asked to the teacher.
exampleCorrections: We ask the assistant for a bag.|I asked the teacher.
explanation: The verb 'ask' is transitive. It takes a direct object (the person being asked) without the preposition 'to'.

exampleErrors: Railroad and highway is the path.|Sachin and Ganguly was my favorite.
exampleCorrections: Railroad and highway are the path.|Sachin and Ganguly were my favorite.
explanation: Subjects joined by 'and' form a plural subject and require a plural verb (are/were/have).

exampleErrors: Raise taxes for pay for the service.|Woke up early for take the train.
exampleCorrections: Raise taxes to pay for the service.|Woke up early to take the train.
explanation: To express purpose with a verb, English uses the to-infinitive ('to pay'), not 'for' + base verb.

exampleErrors: There are a commercial zone.|There are a big problem.
exampleCorrections: There is a commercial zone.|There is a big problem.
explanation: 'There is' must be used when the following noun (the complement) is singular.

exampleErrors: He said the wife is the one responsible.|I checked his pulse and it is okay.
exampleCorrections: He said the wife was the one responsible.|I checked his pulse and it was okay.
explanation: In narratives or reported speech initiated in the past, verbs usually 'backshift' to the past tense (is -> was) to maintain consistency.

exampleErrors: Waiting to find out what the ending will be.|They thought you will help.
exampleCorrections: Waiting to find out what the ending would be.|They thought you would help.
explanation: When looking at the future from a past perspective, 'would' is used instead of 'will'.

exampleErrors: We can be a famous.|I'm a very busy.
exampleCorrections: We can be famous.|I am very busy.
explanation: Adjectives cannot take an article ('a'/'an') unless they are followed by a noun (e.g., 'a famous person').

exampleErrors: If we did this, we can bring a bag.|If I had money, I can travel.
exampleCorrections: If we did this, we could bring a bag.|If I had money, I could travel.
explanation: In the Second Conditional (hypothetical), the main clause uses 'could' or 'would', not 'can'.

exampleErrors: Not good to playing any sports.|It is bad to eating late.
exampleCorrections: Not good for playing any sports.|It is bad for eating late.
explanation: When describing benefit or detriment, the correct collocation is 'good for' or 'bad for' + gerund.

exampleErrors: If it continues, then Indonesia would be the most unclean.|If he goes, I would go too.
exampleCorrections: If it continues, then Indonesia will be the most unclean.|If he goes, I will go too.
explanation: In the First Conditional (real possibility), the result clause uses 'will', not 'would'.

exampleErrors: Travel in public transport.|I was in the bus.
exampleCorrections: Travel on public transport.|I was on the bus.
explanation: We use 'on' for large public transport vehicles where one can stand or walk.

exampleErrors: Public transport have no future.|Egypt have a lot of historical places.
exampleCorrections: Public transport has no future.|Egypt has a lot of historical places.
explanation: Third-person singular subjects (he, she, it, or singular nouns) require the verb 'has', not 'have'.

exampleErrors: The garbage's collection.|A cinema's enthusiast.
exampleCorrections: The garbage collection.|A cinema enthusiast.
explanation: When a noun modifies another noun (Noun Adjunct), we usually place them side-by-side without a possessive 's (e.g., 'computer room', not 'computer's room').

exampleErrors: We should use the bicycle (in general).|I want to buy the car (any car).
exampleCorrections: We should use a bicycle.|I want to buy a car.
explanation: When referring to a non-specific item or introducing it for the first time, use 'a/an' instead of 'the'.

exampleErrors: Instead to using cars.|Instead to going out.
exampleCorrections: Instead of using cars.|Instead of going out.
explanation: The prepositional phrase is 'instead of', which is followed by a gerund.

exampleErrors: It is a pleasure to meeting you.
exampleCorrections: It is a pleasure of meeting you (rare) / pleasure to meet you.
explanation: Standard phrases are 'pleasure to meet' (infinitive) or 'pleasure of meeting' (gerund). 'Pleasure to meeting' mixes both forms incorrectly.

exampleErrors: Ensure that the children could play (general present rule).
exampleCorrections: Ensure that the children can play.
explanation: When describing general facts or present abilities, 'can' is used. 'Could' implies past ability or specific conditions.

exampleErrors: We were in the airport.
exampleCorrections: We were at the airport.
explanation: Public transport hubs (airport, station) are usually viewed as points on a journey, requiring the preposition 'at'.

exampleErrors: On October of 1878.|I was born on July.
exampleCorrections: In October of 1878.|I was born in July.
explanation: Months (without a specific day number) take the preposition 'in'.

exampleErrors: Values are important as it is inherited.|These things are good because it is free.
exampleCorrections: Values are important as they are inherited.|These things are good because they are free.
explanation: A plural antecedent (values, things) must be referenced by 'they', not 'it'.

exampleErrors: A change of our habits.|We need a change of attitude.
exampleCorrections: A change in our habits.|We need a change in attitude.
explanation: When referring to an alteration within a continuing state or pattern, we use 'change in'. 'Change of' often implies substitution (e.g., change of clothes).

exampleErrors: If the world has one language it would be better.
exampleCorrections: If the world had one language it would be better.
explanation: In the Second Conditional (hypothetical), the 'if' clause requires the Past Simple tense.

exampleErrors: Although of it is difficult.|Despite of the rain.
exampleCorrections: Although it is difficult.|Despite the rain / In spite of the rain.
explanation: 'Although' is a conjunction and takes no preposition. 'Despite' is a preposition and does not take 'of'. Only 'In spite' takes 'of'.

exampleErrors: I want to improve in my English.|He improved in his skills.
exampleCorrections: I want to improve my English.|He improved his skills.
